newsitem.title: GERMANY: Reynolds VP sceptical on Russia aluminium restarts.
newsitem.headline: Reynolds VP sceptical on Russia aluminium restarts.

text.p: William Gray Reynolds, a senior vice president at U.S. producer and fabricator Reynolds Metals Co, said he was sceptical about reports Russian aluminium producers might restrain production.
"I don't see any change...the Russians see that (producing aluminium) as a way to earn hard currency, this will continue," Reynolds said in response to questions at a business luncheon on Tuesday.
He also said there were no alternatives uses for the hydroelectric power generated in Russia's aluminium producing regions.
Russia's producers' association Kontsern Alyuminiy said last week smelters had agreed not to raise production from current levels, but would not cut them back.
This was in response to a diplomat report Russian and Canadian officials had met to discuss curbing Russian output.
It also rekindled memories of the two-year Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) between major world producers to cut output and boost prices, which ended this spring.
Reynolds is among the companies with large idled capacity as a late result of the MOU, as aluminium prices have been too unattractive to warrant restarts.
Asked if his company planned any such restarts, Reynolds said, "I don't know of any plan."
